(1) The bodhisattva's deliverance of people is like a skillful wet-nurse raising a child, with four things:
First, bathing to keep them clean; second, feeding them to keep them full; third, making them sleep peacefully; fourth, holding them and going out to always make them happy.
By these four things, the child is nurtured and made to achieve.
The bodhisattva is also like this, nurturing beings with four things:

First, washing away the defilements of the mind with the true Dharma; second, feeding them with the food of the scriptures; third, establishing them in the samÄdhi of meditation at the right time; fourth, always making everyone happy with the four kinds of kindness.
By these four things, everyone is encouraged and nurtured, and beings are made to attain the Way.
(2) In the world, there are two kinds of acquaintances who always become causes and conditions for people, causing people to obtain great offenses and also causing people to obtain great blessings.
What are the two kinds of acquaintances?
One is an evil acquaintance, and the other is a good acquaintance.

It is like a bandit leader who commits heinous crimes, killing rulers and fathers, and causing chaos in the world. Sentient beings are afflicted by calamities and no one is spared. Associating with him causes people to incur great offenses.

It is like ÅšÄkyamuni Bodhisattva who, upon giving rise to the intention to seek the Way, saves and protects sentient beings. With the four means of unification and the four kinds of kindness, he embraces and protects all, and none in the three realms and five paths are not liberated by him!
This is called a good acquaintance. Associating with him causes people to obtain great blessings.
(3) In the past, there was a country in southern India called Sihejie, located on an island in the ocean, with a city over 80,000 li long and wide.

At that time, there was an old woman in another country named Alu, who, due to the chaos of war, drifted to this country. Alone and without a place to return to, she begged for a living. She went to a wealthy family and wanted to seek shelter.
When the elder's wife saw her, she asked after the old woman, and the old woman fully explained her intentions of poverty and hardship.
The elder was moved with pity and said to the old woman:
You may stay in my house. I will provide for you.
The old woman joyfully said:
I have nothing to repay you. I will do some small tasks for you and will not dare to be lazy in my work!
So she stayed there.
She felt both sad and happy:
In the past, I served the monks and provided whatever they needed. Today, I suddenly find myself in poverty and hardship, and my mind of giving is not fulfilled. I feel deeply moved within.
She then bowed to the monk and asked:
I wonder if the monks have had their morning meal?
The monk replied:
We came into the city this morning to beg for alms, but we got nothing, so we returned to where we were.
The old woman then thought:
I want to offer a meal to the monks, but I myself have nothing.
She said to the monks:
I will now enter the city to look. If I can obtain the offerings, I will return and report.
If not, I will also make them aware of the news.
Then the assembly agreed and each left the tree.
Then the old woman returned home and informed the elder's wife, who needed several thousand coins:
Although I am now working here as a servant, I wish to sell myself and become a servant for life. Can we draw up a contract?
The elder's wife asked:
You rely on me for clothing and food here. Why do you suddenly need money?
What will you use it for?
The old woman said:
It is a private urgent need, I cannot speak of it.
Then the elder's wife gave her the money and said:
Take it and use it. If you have the time, you can return it yourself. Why do I need a contract?
The old woman received the money and went to her acquaintances from before, telling them the situation:
Give this money to each person and have them prepare food for sixty families.
In a short while, it was all done, and she brought it to the monk.
I originally thought it was not real, but when I arrived at the city, it was like this.
They all marveled at her diligence, which was beyond their expectations, and asked the old woman:
Where do you live?
I have been begging for alms in the streets, but why have I never seen you?
The old woman told them the whole story from beginning to end:
I am a person from such-and-such a country. My family originally served the Buddha and made offerings to the Sangha.

When the world was in chaos, I fled here, and my family was completely destroyed. I am alone and destitute, relying on a great elder's family in this country, working for them and depending on their clothes and food. My empty body is entrusted to life, and I don't have a single coin.
Seeing the ascetic, I was filled with sorrow and joy, my heart was burdened with thoughts, and my compassionate vow was not fulfilled.
I told my wife:
'I am selling myself to seek a little bit of money to offer food to the assembly of monks.'
Out of compassion, she pitied me and allowed me to fulfill my sincere wish.
The ascetic sighed and said:
This is truly called exhausting one's faith and offerings!
They all said to each other:
We too are bodies of the five aggregates, going out to beg for alms. Today's food is like eating human flesh. We should each set our minds to repay the merit of the offerings.

The group of people unified their minds and established the eight forms of meditation, diligently and sincerely connecting with the numinous, immediately attaining transcendent concentration, with the power of spiritual feet and majestic spiritual power shaking the realm, the trees bending over as if kneeling in worship.
The ascetic saw the realization and praised the donor.
The king was startled and wondered why this was so. He summoned the ministers to discuss together:
Investigating the auspicious response, what is the cause of this?
The ministers went out in all four directions to investigate the reason. They saw that outside the city gates, the roads were crowded with people, and the givers were bustling, rejoicing together.
They then entered and reported to the king, who said:
This is exactly what I want, quickly invite her to come!
The ministers returned and proclaimed the king's decree.
The old mother was frightened and feared there would be misfortune. She replied to the ministers:
I am bound to the wife of the elder and do not have freedom.
The ministers returned and reported this intention. The king said:
Invite her and her master to come.
Then the wife of the elder, upon hearing the king's decree, went with the old mother to the king's place.
The king asked about the matter, and the old mother fully explained the details to the king.
The king said:

I am the lord of the country, rich and free, yet I do not know how to respectfully serve the Three Jewels and make offerings to the Daoist practitioners, like this old mother who has attained such a response!
The king said:
This mother is my teacher.
He was welcomed into the palace, bathed with fragrant hot water, and sat in the teacher's seat.
The twenty thousand palace ladies and concubines, and the king himself, received the precepts and became upÄsakas;
The elderly ladies and concubines became upÄsikÄs.
All the people of the country universally aroused the aspiration for enlightenment.
(4) In the past, a practitioner studied the Way in the mountains.
There were many poisonous snakes in the mountains, and the practitioner feared them. He relied on the foot of a tree, spread his bed high, sat in meditation and contemplated concentration;
But he only suffered from sleep and could not control himself.

The heavenly person then laughed in the sky, awakened him, and he finally fell asleep. Not understanding the heavenly person's intention, he made a expedient means, wanting to frighten him so that he would not sleep too much.
At night, the heavenly person said:
Oh, oh, practitioner, a poisonous snake is coming!
The practitioner was greatly frightened and lit a lamp, searching everywhere but not seeing it.
The heavenly person repeatedly did not stop, and the practitioner became even more angry, saying:
Why do you, heavenly person, commit slander?
I don't see anything at all, so how can you say it's a poisonous snake?
The heavenly person said to the practitioner:
Why don't you observe the poisonous snake within yourself?
If you don't eliminate the four snakes in the body, how can you seek them outside?
When the practitioner heard the heavenly person's words, he immediately contemplated:
Observing the body and its contents, I now know that the four elements are submerged in the five aggregates and six sense faculties, and have not been liberated for countless eons.
He then understood the four noble truths, suffering, emptiness, and non-self.
Before dawn, his defilements were exhausted, his mind was liberated, and he attained the six supernormal powers and became an arhat.
(5) In the past, there was King Asoka who built 1,200 stupas and temples within his territory. Later, he became seriously ill.

The monk said to the king:

With palms joined and a focused mind, he caused the king to see all the stupas in the realm.
The monk then manifested his spiritual powers, and in an instant, 1,200 stupas were all in front of the king.
Seeing this, he was overjoyed, and his illness immediately disappeared. He took golden banners and golden flowers and hung them on the stupas. The low and high stupas all came to the king's hands.
The king regained his original body and his illness was cured. He immediately had a great thought and extended his life for twenty-five years. He then made merit and attained irreversibility.

(8) In the past, there was a king who enjoyed eating human flesh. He ordered his cooks:
You should secretly capture people at night to supply the kitchen.
This became a regular practice.
Later, the ministers all found out about it and expelled him to the borderlands, seeking a virtuous and wise person to be their king instead.

After that, the cannibal king, thirteen years later, grew two wings on his body and flew around eating people, without any distance being too far. He went to the mountain tree spirit and prayed for blessings:
I will capture the king and five hundred people to offer to the mountain tree spirit, enabling me to return to the country and become king again.
So he flew to get them, and obtained 499 people, and put them in a mountain valley with stones sealing the entrance.

At that time, the king of the country was going to the bathing pond with his harem to play. Just as he was leaving the palace, he encountered a mendicant who spoke a verse begging for alms. The king immediately agreed and said he would bestow gold and silver upon his return to the palace.
At that time, the king entered the pond and was about to bathe when the king of man-eaters flew through the air and carried the king away to return to the mountains.
When the king of the country saw the king of man-eaters, he was neither afraid nor terrified, his expression was as usual.
The king of man-eaters said:

I originally captured 500 people to offer to the heavens as a sacrifice. I already have 499 people, and now I have obtained you, one person. The number is already full, so I will kill you to offer to the heavens.
You know this, so why are you not afraid?
The king of the country replied:
People are born to die, things that are formed will decay, what comes together will eventually separate, I am resigned to fate, I dare not be sorrowful!
When I left the palace in the morning, I encountered a Daoist who spoke a verse for me, and I promised to give him things, but I haven't been able to give them to him yet. This is what I regret.
Now, Your Majesty is compassionate and forgiving. If I am given a few days to finish my giving, I will not go back on my vow.
He then allowed him to leave and told him:
I will give you seven days. If you do not return, I will come and take you away without any difficulty.

The king then returned to the palace. Inside and outside the city, everyone rejoiced. He opened the treasury and gave alms to the far and near. He appointed his crown prince as king, comforted the people, and left.
The cannibal king saw him coming from afar and thought:
Could this be an extraordinary person?
He has returned from death.
He then asked:
Life and body are what worldly people value and love the most. The faith you have in giving up your life is rare in the world. I wonder what you uphold and pursue?
Please explain its meaning.
He said:
My compassionate giving and sincere vow is to attain the supreme enlightenment and liberate the ten directions.
The king said:

He then extensively explained the five precepts, ten wholesome [deeds], four immeasurable [minds], and six perfections.
His mind opened up and he became enlightened. He received the five precepts and became a lay devotee. He released 499 people, each to return to their own country.

The kings who followed the last king together went to his country. Moved by his sincere vow, they were saved and their lives were spared. They each refused to return to their own countries and thus stayed in this country.
In this country, each king established the foremost house, carved with engravings, shining and splendid. The food and clothing of the foreign kings were no different from the king's.
People from all directions asked:

The people answered:ğŸ”½The king of this country, named Xiliang, was originally a king of a foreign country. The name thus spread far and wide.

After the Buddha attained enlightenment, he spoke of his past:

The king who established faith is none other than myself. The king who ate people is Angulimala. Returning to Rajagriha to expound the Dharma, he liberated countless beings, all of whom were people he had karmic connections with when he was a king in his past lives!
When the Buddha spoke this, there was none who did not rejoice, attain blessings, and attain liberation, beyond measure.
(9) In the past, in the Himalayas, there was a white elephant king with six tusks who gave birth to 20,000 elephants.
The elephant king had two wives, one older and one younger, who always accompanied him to the left and right when he went out to play.
Once, when the king went out to play, he passed by a large tree with luxuriant flowers. He wanted to take the flowers to adorn his two wives.
The wind blew the tree flowers and they fell only on the chief consort, not on the other consorts who were downwind. They thought the king was biased and gave rise to poisonous thoughts within.

Later, in the king's pond, a golden lotus flower with a thousand petals grew. A young elephant saw it, picked it up, and offered it to the king. The king gave it to the chief consort to wear on her head.
The other consorts became even more jealous and resentful, thinking of harming the king.

In the Himalayas, there were many practitioners. The other consorts then offered delicious fruits to a hundred pratyekabuddhas every day. Later, on a mountain peak overlooking a steep cliff, she made a vow:
With the merit and virtue of offering to the pratyekabuddhas before and after, may I be reborn among humans, have power and status, remember my past lives, and kill this elephant king.
She then threw herself off the mountain and died.
The spirit was reborn among humans as the daughter of an elder, with clear wisdom, far-reaching understanding, and incomparable beauty.
When the girl grew up, the king betrothed her to be his wife, and he loved and valued her.
The wife thought to herself:
Now I have truly obtained retribution for my past grudges!
She then used turmeric to yellow her face and lay down claiming to be sick.
The king entered to ask about it, and she replied:
Last night I dreamed of an elephant with six tusks on its head. I want to obtain its tusks to make earrings.
If the king cannot obtain these elephant tusks, my illness will worsen day by day!
The king naturally valued her and did not dare disobey her wishes. He immediately summoned several hundred hunters from the country and told them:
Have you seen a white elephant with six tusks in the mountains?
They all said:
We have never seen it!
The king was displeased.
He had the wife call the hunters and discuss this matter together.
The wife said:
There really is no such elephant nearby. Who among you is able to endure hardship and be bold?
A man knelt for a long time and said:
I am the most suitable!
Then the queen gave him ten thousand taels of gold, an iron hook, an axe, a chisel, and a set of Dharma robes, and told him:

Go straight to the Snow Mountains. On the way, there will be a large tree with pythons on the left and right, hundreds of feet long, that cannot be approached. Use the axe and chisel to bore through the tree and pass through it.
Go forward and you will see a large body of water with trees overhanging the water. Use the iron hook to hook the trees, follow the branches, and go forward to where the elephants live.
Look for a place where they usually stop, dig a deep pit there, and cover it thinly. Wait in it for the elephants to come, and shoot them with arrows.
Then put on the saffron robes like a Å›ramaá¹‡a. The elephants revere the Three Jewels and will never harm you.
The hunter accepted the instructions and left. On the seventh day of the seventh month of the seventh year, he arrived at the place where the elephants lived and dug a pit to hide in it.
Soon the elephant king returned, and the hunter shot him with a poisoned arrow. The elephant, not going far, used his trunk to scoop out the ground and saw the man in the pit. He asked:
Who are you?
The man was terrified and confessed:
I am the man who was hired.
The elephant king then knew it was the queen's doing and cut off his tusks to give to the hunter.
He told the man:
You may return, but if the other elephants see you, they will harm you. Tell them to go away, and the herd will surely follow your tracks.
The elephant king used his majestic power to protect him, and within seven days he escaped from their territory and returned to his own country. He gave the tusks to the queen.
The queen, upon receiving them, looked at them over and over again, both happy and regretful. Soon she vomited blood and died.
